data.title: President Chirac
data.meta_description: Like many aspirants to reside in the Élysée Palace, Jacques Chirac tried to create a buzz by publishing a book several months before officially announcing his candidacy on November 4, 1994.1 In La France Pour Tous, he despaired at the malaise and fatalism...
data.text:
Like many aspirants to reside in the Élysée Palace, Jacques Chirac tried to create a buzz by publishing a book several months before officially announcing his candidacy on November 4, 1994.1 In La France Pour Tous, he despaired at the malaise and fatalism afflicting France and called on citizens to adopt a positive outlook: “France is in trouble… Ultimately we are at the point of thinking we can do nothing… These renunciations sometimes take on the seductive colors of modernity… Everything that is not conformist is denounced as unreasonable, irresponsible or insolent… I have come to tell the French that it is their time to renounce renunciation.”2 He repeatedly condemned the “monarchial drift” of Mitterrand“s government and pledged to be a more “modest” president.

Gaullism… is a demand for truth in the service of the only worthy cause: that of France, its grandeur, its unity, and the example of humanism that it has the duty to set for the rest of the world.

—Jacques Chirac
